section.title: Overview
section.para: The Orders functions are used to pay and process orders in the system. Orders can be paid via electronic or paper services and remitted though these features. In addition, File uploads for invoices and other documents can be performed through the File upload function.

section.para: The Services menu is selected by clicking Services on the menu bar. This will display a menu of functions for selection.
The following functions are available in the Services menu.

Customise the default jurisdiction set-up created by the bank.

Data Maintenance

Each of these functions are described in more detail in the following sections.

section.title: Jurisdiction Maintenance
section.para: As an administrator at a client company, you use the Jurisdiction Maintenance function to customise the default jurisdiction set-up created by the bank.

Jurisdiction defines the maximum amount of money that each user is authorised to submit a transaction for. Each user is given a property called a role, and each role has a maximum transaction amount associated with it for each product. If a transaction amount is above the amount allowed by the user's role, the transaction will be saved but not sent to the bank. Another user with the necessary authorisation must then send the transaction.

For higher transaction amounts, or more hierarchical company organisations, the maximum amount can also be defined for a combination of two roles. In such a case the transaction must first be checked by a user with a controller profile (role 1), and then signed by a user with a sign profile (role 2). This authorisation jurisdiction system can therefore force a validation by two users as well as the input user (known as a six-eyes validation).

The authorisation amounts are expressed in the company's base currency. Whenever a transaction is submitted, a middle rate conversion is used to compare the transaction amount with these maximum authorisation amounts. The rates are fetched from the 's rate table.

section.title: User Maintenance
section.para: As an administrator at a client company, you use the User Maintenance module to create, modify or delete user accounts at your company, define the permissions granted to those users, and reset user passwords.

section.title: Terminology
section.para: The term "account" is used in the sense it is normally used in software, to mean a user's registration with a system enabling him or her to log in - not in the everyday banking sense of a place to keep money.

section.title: User Maintenance Options
section.para: The User Maintenance options are part of the System Features menu. They are as follows:

listitem.para: Maintain user accounts. A user's account details are called his or her profile. You can create new accounts, update existing accounts, and delete existing accounts. You cannot delete your own account. A company's main default administrator account can only be deleted by the bank. When you create a new user account, you are then shown a link to set up the user's permissions.

Assign permissions to users. You do this by granting roles, which are sets of permissions. These permissions define which modules of the user can use, and what amount of money the user can submit transactions for when dealing with each bank.

Manage users' entities, by associating entities with users. A user's entities defines the scope of transactions that user can access. It enables the company to attach users to departments or branches.
Reset user passwords.

section.title: Data Maintenance
section.para: As an administrator at a client company, you use the Data Maintenance module to maintain various lists of data useful to your company - details of counterparties, frequently used phrases, and so on.

These are the lists that are invoked through popup windows in the transactional modules (see the User Manual - Client), generally by clicking a magnifying glass icon. For example, in the module, the beneficiary is selected from such a list.

section.title: Data Maintenance Options
section.para: The Data Maintenance options are part of the System Features menu. They are as follows:

listitem.para: Maintain the list of available customer counterparties, that is, companies that your company can deal with. They can be beneficiaries of Letters of Credit, Banker's Guarantees and Fund Transfers, transportation companies for Shipping Guarantees, or drawees for Export Documentary Collections.

Maintain the list of available bank counterparties, that is, banks that your company can deal with (other than those where your company has accounts). They can be, for example, the optional Advising Bank for a Letter of Credit or the Presenting Bank for an Export Collection.

Maintain the list of your company's bank accounts. These are typically specified in a transaction to tell the bank which accounts to debit or credit (for example, for debit of charges and commissions).
Maintain the list of frequently used phrases. These are chunks of predefined texts that a user can include in the narrative fields that appear on many forms.

As an administrator at a client company, you use the Alerts module to specify, for a given product and transaction type or milestone date, the users who are to receive alerts.

section.para: As an administrator at a client company, you use the Report Designer module to design reports, which can then be run by all users in your company. These reports cover the products available in such as letters of credit, guarantees, and so on.

The form for designing a report has a checkbox labelled Publish Report. As long as you do not tick this, the report is not made available to your users even if you save it. The report is said to be not executable. When you have finished designing the report and want to release it so users can execute it, you should then tick this checkbox.

section.title: Terminology
section.para: In this chapter, we use the word "report" to mean a report design, rather than an actual generated report. Thus for example "updating a report" means updating the specification of the report, rather than generating a new report with the latest figures.

For example, say a client initiates a Letter of Credit for 1000 GBP. That creates a transaction. When the bank approves it, a master is created. Whichever type you select for your first product - master, transaction, or template - the dropdown list for subsequent products you add offers you only that type. section.title: Report Designer - Schedule
section.para: As an administrator at a client company, you use the Schedule Report module to schedule reports to be executed automatically at a given frequency, with the results sent to a specified recipient via email. There is no need for any user to actually be connected to while a scheduled report is running. The report is executed as if it was being run by a user with access to the company's full jurisdiction (that is, with access to all available permissions given to the company and all its entities). You can select the format (CSV, Spreadsheet or PDF) of the results sent as an email attachment and the language in which the report is generated.
You cannot customise the actual time of day when a scheduled report is executed. This is configured in the technical properties of the GTP application and defined by the Bank technical administrator.
